job_title: Strategic Communications Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: The custom network benefits at MU are unbeatable. This is really only best for people who don't leave town very often. In-network providers are limited to mostly local clinicians or providers working for the MU health system.
cons: Leadership is often inconsistent. People are always leaving and new onboards have their own ideas, leaving you to start over with new goals every few years. You're also left at the whim of MO elected officials, whose political agendas often result in job layoffs. Even if you are spared from layoffs, you learn to pinch every penny of a university budget. In my time there, if I got a raise, it was never more than 2 percent annually. If you're looking for a big bump in pay, you'll have to switch jobs. BUT, university policy prohibits more than a 5 percent increase in pay for lateral moves (without an appeal).

job_title: Strategic Communications Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: Custom benefits plan is unbeatable. Virtually no co-pays or deductibles for those who live and work in the Columbia area.
cons: Resources are always tight at a public university, so you're always searching for ways to stretch a dollar. Knowing that state politics affects your livelihood is stressful. Budget cuts tend to hurt personnel first because they don't want to cut student programs. Certain academic units and departments can be depressing places for staff members. Some faculty hold staff in higher regard, while others treat them as the "hired help." People tend to stay in their jobs for a long time, so while turnover typically isn't an issue (except when budget cuts lead to layoffs), but career advancement opportunities are few. People around the university tend to say, "if you want a pay raise, you have to switch jobs" (however, there is an HR policy in place to prevent lateral moves for this purpose).

job_title: Senior Child Development Teacher in Columbia, MO
pros: Working with the kids and program planning was great, enjoyed supervising staff, coworkers were great and fun to work with
cons:
Management did not appreciate differences nor hard work except by a select few. Rarely backed my decisions. Low morale due to rare shows of support. 12 full time employees have quit in the last 16 months. Dedicated 15 years of my life to this organization only to be treated so badly at the end that I quit without notice. After 15 tears of dedication, the University gave me a lapel pin and a letter about a budget crunch. Unacceptable. They really know how to make you feel like the lesser there. Must go through the same orientation year after year. I sat through it 15 times when policy changes could have been made aware to me via email. Set the workplace up like a big competition and a volleyball team. I know that makes no sense but if you're in it you totally understand really quick. You get good vibes working with the kids and planning your specific site and that sucks you into stay then at the office it is horrible. You must look and act a certain way to get ahead and at that there is little to no advancement. Borders on racist and transphobic. Not forward thinking when it comes to tuition. At a time when Adventure Club is hurting for families and kids, they raised rates when they really should lower rates to pack kids in there. Take all kids regardless of their SES. They take state aid for a limited number of kids and have a meager scholarship program. I gave a forward thinking idea to upper management about lowering rates by half thereby getting a higher enrollment but was quickly shot down. I understand a difference of opinion but these are kids needing care. 

To all these reasons Adventure Club is not living up to their mission statement of, "enhancing the growth and development of the children, families, staff, and communities we serve." Or is that a lie?

job_title: Nutrition Educator in Kansas City, MO
pros: I worked for the state extension office in Kansas City. I would review them specifically but I do not think they have a specific profile. That said-- this is the best job I have ever had. Everyone is friendly, nice, passionate and laid back. You get important and fun work done without wanting to pull your hair out every day. You also get to go back to school virtually for free, which makes up for lower salary. Also, the work life balance here is unbeatable.
cons: There are cons in every work place, I found the cons here to be manageable. A lot of the employees are very open about their religious beliefs which can be uncomfortable (no one has ever tried to convert me but I've heard loud gospel music playing around the office and watched groups prayers before meals). This isn't really coming from the higher ups, though, just from employees. Pay isn't great for lower level educator positions but it's average for extensions across the country and you'll never work over-time because you are hourly. It's also hard to move-up unless you have graduate degree. Additionally, there isn't a lot of flexibility with the curriculums (I worked in the nutrition department and the recipes were pretty awful and outdated).

pros: NONE NADA ZILCH, A BIG ZERO

Plenty! where do I even start:
1)Hostile work environment. Intimidating employees and threatening to fire them is an everyday occurrence.

Please stay away for your own mental well-being and peace of mind.

All in all, if you have other options please consider them and you will never regret. Working here is an absolute horror.

pros: Like a couple of my coworkers
cons: No leadership, boss never around and awful when there, nowhere near the deserved salary

pros: Worked at MOI outpatient PT, with 18-20 other therapists. PT appointments are 45 minutes one-on-one for the most part with each patient, which is great. Rare to double book. Great opportunities for continued education. Close relationship with orthopedic and PM&R physician teams. See wide variety of patient age, population, chronicity, pathologies, not just surgical patients. Surgical team is committed to conservative care attempts prior to surgical intervention.  Opportunities to work in other areas of MOI other than just as a line therapist. All therapy staff is great, friendly, fun, and committed to sharing knowledge. Great place to work. I can't speak for the other Mizzou Therapy Clinics, but the system is considered the premiere system in the area.
cons: Can be a very busy clinic when all therapists are there.  It is a large clinic, so double-booking can be hard to keep an eye on two patients. The PT-techs are only for clinic maintenance, and do not interact with the patients for the most part, hence the difficulty with double-booking, though it is rare. Clinic is always expanding into new opportunities, which sometimes takes line therapists out of rotation to work on other opportunities, leading to more load on other line therapists.

job_title: Web & Social Media Administrator in Columbia, MO
pros:
If you like a higher-ed environment, Mizzou is great. From my experience as a graduate student and then full-time employee, people enjoy working for the university. It's an upbeat, friendly and focused environment and in my experience there, working with students was great. The Student Affairs Division is a lot of fun. 

Benefits are good, lots of staff development opportunities, access to great campus amenities.
cons:
Standard politics that come with a state institution. Plenty of talk around money, enrollment, how departments are expected to invest in the greater university, etc. It's not unusual to find employees who should have been let go a long time ago. Depending on the department, there's not much room for growth within the department; growth potential if you're willing to move around the university. 

Due to budget restrictions many schools face(d), Mizzou had a hiring and raise freeze while I was there. If I remember correctly, employees received the standard 2% raise once in a five year period. Plus side is that the school was committed to 1) raising tuition as little as possible and 2) not eliminating staff positions. You may not have gotten a raise, but I never felt like my job was in jeopardy.

pros: Good job if you want to work alone, no formal attire required, laid-back attitude, can make one's own schedule as long as enough samples are being processed and enough experiments are put it, can slightly tweak lab procedures if something doesn't work for you, no boss hanging over you telling you how every detail should be done, not your typical 9-to-5 job where you punch in and out because your hours are flexible.
cons: Not much room to advance without a science degree, lots of hard, dirty work, very isolated part of campus, job can become quite monotonous, may have to communicate with farmers who don't write legibly on soil admission forms or who send samples in non-secure packaging, a lot less work available in the winter and early springs when samples aren't being taken.

pros: Satisfaction of providing a service to the citizens of Missouri. Good benefits. Opportunity for creativity. Lots of great people on staff to work with. Collaborative spirit across many departments. Nice community to live in.
cons: Loyalty cost to loyal, longterm employees - our salaries are less and less comparable to employees outside the institution and to new employees coming into the system. Salary discrepancies and unfairness - employees doing the same/comparable work can be paid much more just by being in a different department a few doors down the hall. Employees may be requested to do the work of more than one person but without recognition or salary compensation. It's possible for a salaried (non-hourly) employee to be asked to do very large amounts of overtime (at no compensation because they are salaried). Job title manipulation in which an employee's actual job description does not match their job title, allowing the institution to pay for a lesser skill set while demanding work requiring a higher skill set. Lack of trust of some managers. Inconsistent messages from managers across functional departments can be confusing.

pros: I really enjoyed my employment as a site assistant at MU Adventure Club. As site assistants we assisted with morning and afternoon programming including games, snack, outdoor activities, gym activities, and educational activities. It was also fun meeting fellow MU students during my time there; all our staff still remain friends with one another. The staff were always friendly and helpful; we ran our afternoon program efficiently.  MU Adventure Club also provided many opportunities for training including CPR and First Aid Training, Food Safety (i.e. food allergies and medications), also it was fun to get to know all the kids at the elementary school I worked at!
cons: There are specific student to teacher ratios and you had to be very aware at all times while taking the students outside or to the gym to keep headcounts and monitor safety as necessary. The ratios were 12:1 so it was certainly manageable and I had other site assistants helping monitor each rotation we had for our group of students.

review_title: Mizzou is doing a lot to make life better for graduate assistants
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: Mizzou leadership has done a lot to improve salaries for graduate assistants since I first started in 2011. Additionally, they continue to offer paid health insurance. While each department is different, in my department, leadership saw grad assistants as students first, and most faculty were flexible if you needed more time for your studies at critical times in the semester, as long as you were willing to make up for it if asked to do something extra during slower times. I was always given real research work to do, and very little in the way of administrative tasks such as copying.
cons: Currently, most assistantships run for only 9 months and it can be difficult to find a summer appointment. Also, because of new employment rules, you are limited to working 28 hours per week, and most jobs are 20 or 10, so you can work two positions, but you'll only get paid for 28 hours.

review_title: Sometimes frustrating but overall a good place to work
pros: The campus is absolutely beautiful and the town of Columbia is a great place to live.  There are chances to move up within the University if you are in the top of your field, or connected/related to top administration.
cons: Nepotism is rampant as is the good ole boy mentality.  Most promotions and openings are filled by relatives of employees and their friends.  The University structure is very fractured and there is little oversight or governance from the top administrators.  Staff is generally not highly valued by the top administrators and especially not by the faculty.  There is a large baby boomer problem.  University funds are tied up by salaries and benefits of the older and overpaid generation who produce very little.  This strongly discourages young capable staff members to stay as their chances of moving up are typically blocked.

review_title: Solid benefits and great atmosphere - limited advancement opportunities
pros: It's an institute of higher learning, so the atmosphere is great - generally nice people, beautiful surroundings.  Good benefits - spouse / children reduced tuition, nice amount of vacation, health insurance is well subsidized.  I'm on the old (better) retirement plan, so I can't speak to the new one.
cons: There can be limited advancement opportunities, because a lot of people are fairly entrenched in their positions, and unlikely to go anywhere before retirement.  This speaks well of the University, but it can be kind of frustrating.  There are certainly opportunities, but one often has to move between departments if you want to get anywhere.

pros: The university is located in a beautiful small town that feels homey and safe. It's a great place to work as a recent graduate or while you or a significant other are in school.
cons: As with most public institutions of higher education, the pay is not great, but the cost of living in Columbia is low, so it's manageable. The bureaucracy can be infuriating for staff members -- knowledge sharing between departments, schools, and divisions seemed nonexistent to me at times, which was detrimental to all those who were working in PR and new media like I was.

review_title: Wonderful learning experience as a Reservations Ambassador at University of Missouri
pros: Your coworkers are kind. The work you are doing is very applicable to any job out of college. This job is especially great for Communication majors and students looking to get involved with event planning. The supervisors are kind as long as you don't make many mistakes. You are paid well for a student employee. My overall experience at the job was pleasant.
cons: Supervisors can be very strict and nit-picky. I did not feel that I was given ample time to make it from work to my classes and was often late to my lectures. There isn't really any room for promotions in this position. The office culture is nice at most times but could get very tense at times as well. Can be a very overwhelming job at times if the office is busy.

job_title: Building Operations Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: It was a good job for students as it allowed a good balance of time between work and school. I was able to take off for review sessions that got scheduled during my shift a couple of times, and I was able to take off for a career fair too.
cons: My biggest complaint at Mizzou is the upper management. They are out of touch, they believe their ideas are good without listening to a dissenting opinion, they don't care for the students at all, but then say the next day they are doing this for the students. Overall they are hypocritical, and the changes that need to made are ignored as it isn't marketable. A good example would be not buying new equipment to move furniture around the student center as that costs money, but spending countless money on fliers and advertisements throughout the student center about a pancake breakfast.

job_title: Supervisor Dining and Nutrition in Columbia, MO
pros: I was able to affect people's lives in a positive supportive way.  I had opportunity to work with programs like Job Point and other programs to employee people who could develop into a productive staff with training who may not have been exposed to the basic job skills needed in this job market.
cons: Management is all about politics if it is the correct thing to do but not in the current directors plan to move up in pay grade, then your efforts to support your employees in growing in their work positions will be undermined and overridden because it is not the focus.  The university is very biased in who may excel and be promoted.  If you are honest and follow the University Hospitals Code of Conduct, you can be terminated if you insist on calling attention to discrimination and improper actions by management.

review_title: Health & Behavioral Risk Research Center employee
pros: The work isn't difficult, but the training requires going through a lot of information about human research and confidentiality. After about a week of using the software it all becomes second nature. Many workers read, color, or solve puzzles while working to pass the time. The hours are a bit flexible, and call-ins aren't penalized. Making up missed hours is fairly easy, and working extra is allowed, provided it is less than 40hr/wk.
cons: The work is utterly boring - making repetive phone calls to walk people through a research survey. Sometimes respondents will become hostile and abusive, and we are required to attempt to persuade them to participate anyway. While the hours are flexible, they are grouped in 4-hour shifts and 80% of scheduled time must be either after 5pm weekdays or on the weekends, and two shifts must be Friday night, Saturday, or Sunday. Any makeup hours must be done during these preferred times, as well. Employees are not allowed to use their phones on the call center floor, and can be sent home for doing so.

review_title: Job Security is great, opportunities are not
pros: The best part about working at UMKC is that you have a VERY secure job.  You also have great flexibility working here, as most units are quite flexible on vacation and sick leave and there are some opportunities to work from home.
cons: The downside of working at UMKC as a staff member is that there is no promotion system.  Whatever position you are hired in at, no matter how exemplary your work, there is no place to promote to in most situations, and as such, no incentive for growth.  Also, whether you do well or do poorly seems to have no impact on your job status or your chances of getting a pay raise.  Either there is money and everyone gets a raise, or there is not, and no one gets a raise.

review_title: Not the "real world" but a great place to work
job_title: Office Support Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: Good benefits including retirement, time-off leave, and holidays.  Depending on the department, it can be a low stress environment.  Most people are friendly and want to do a good job.
cons: Raises are rare so always negotiate the highest salary possible.  Employees are reviewed annually, but it is difficult to reward good employees with small raises and in many cases no raises.  Unfortunately, the only way to get a raise is to have an offer and sometimes they will match to keep you if you are a good employee. Management listens to employees, but seems powerless to enact improvements which often come at a snail's pace.  Long-term employees are not valued.  New employees without experience are often paid nearly the same as long-term employees.  Many employees are burnt out and have little to no incentive to improve or move on.

review_title: Great place to work in college
pros: Tutoring is a lot of fun, and can be really rewarding. You get the opportunity to really help other students not just to survive a class, but actually like the material.
cons:
There's not a huge downside to this job. The pay is on par with other campus jobs and your hours are very flexible; you basically set your own hours. 

The one complaint I had, though it was no fault of the Student Success Center, was that there was no often little or no coordination between professors and tutors. Since tutors worked face-to-face with students, we learned what worked and what didn't in terms of teaching the material. In no way am I claiming that tutors could do professors' job better than the actual professors, but I believe we had some valuable input to give. There was really no systematic or formal way to do this. Perhaps in the future, there will be, and that would certainly be a good thing for the students we were there to help.

pros: Great environment to work. People that cared about how and what you were doing both professionally and academically. I had a chance to work with people that needed my help and I enjoyed what I did. I had some of the most rewarding days I have ever had in my working career.
cons: I am not sure that were many cons to share. Outside of the pay I cannot see a con of working for this institution. This is not a place that a person could support a growing family with one income and have a high level of education unless that person was in a high position within the structure of the University.

pros: Generally has good job security, the staff employee culture is generally very friendly and helpful, lots of great people here.  Excellent benefits and more time off than I know what to do with.
cons: Academia is a little different world from the private sector and there do exist a certain number of people that think they are entitled to whatever they want whenever they want it simply because they are faculty or because of their title.

review_title: Great benefits, too many meetings, ok pay
job_title: Procurement Specialist in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good benefits, educational environment promotes learning and working together. Medical, dental, vision, drug coverage all great. Also 75% tuition remission policy can help finance employee's own education (50% also for spouse and kids after five years of working there). Supports community-based economic development efforts, as well as a wide array of other outreach programs -- it's more than just the classrooms in Columbia, way more.
cons: Excessive travel for professional development and meetings that could easily be done locally.  Inconsistent policies for reimbursement of said travel expenses (conflicts between Federal grant regulations and campus policies). Pay is somewhat low compared to private industry, but high compared to the rest of state government and compared to local government.

review_title: Good start point but not for the creative and outside box thinkers or long term career.
pros: Nice perks of working with Rec Services. Very good training programs. Lots of social functions and student development activities. Lots of conference attendance allowed.
cons: Very rigid and fixed system of doing things. Very stuck in tradition. Do not utilize peoples experiences and expertise as much as they should. Communication not always made clear on what is expected. Opportunities for personal professional development is minimal and narrow to those that benefit only the department. Pay is far below what work is being put in for time alone.

review_title: Good pay.  But this school is run by people that hate academics.
pros: The pay is pretty good and as long as you aren't really interested in having support to do your research, you may like it.  The teaching load is very reasonable.
cons: The place is starved for money to support faculty research.  At the same time they don't really care about the quality of student education.  Generally, this school is treated as an annoying necessity by the conservative state government.

review_title: Decent first job, just don't stay too long
pros: Not very stressful, decent benefits, fun environment, varying project types, ability to take control of larger projects to build portfolio.
cons: Pay isn't anywhere near industry standards, slow-paced environment that leads to boredom at best, and decline in skills at worst. You won't often be challenged, and when you are it's usually when trying to do something new. The university doesn't move as slow as government work, but they're not anywhere near as fast as private industry. You will get rusty and become irrelevant in your industry if you stay too long.

review_title: School of medicine- "you'll do what we want you to do"
pros: Nice people, clean inviting workplace, flexible schedule if needed and consideration for staff with young children/family responsibilities.
cons: Higher-ups don't seem to understand the workload of those under them. No raises, annual evaluations can be biased based on personal interactions with one's administrators. Abundance of unnecessary meetings, activities recurring annually can be time consuming and take lots of time out of a day, rather than hiring within they pull from outside resulting in support staff "training" their higher ups without compensation or recognition. Involuntary mandated policy/rule adjustments are made on short notice. Employees are told their valued, but otherwise not recognized for the hard work they do.

review_title: Opportunities exist but benefits are poor for those not in tenured roles
job_title: Graduate Instructor and Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: I was a graduate assistant and instructor.  It was a great learning experience and I was able to land my current position based on my research experience.
cons: The pay for grad asst's is not great.  No one expects that.  However, the kerfuffle with the insurance happened shortly after I left and even before that, health insurance was a high-deductible nightmare.  Arts and Science also is cracking down on moonlighting.  The last two years I was there, getting a second job could have cost me my fellowship and assistantship.

job_title: Office Support Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: Good benefits! Great coworkers. Perform work that makes a difference. Flexibility in taking vacation as long as you get your  work done and have someone to cover for you. Stable work that it somewhat secure.
cons: Management is slow to change. Difficult to get rid of unnecessary employees. Little to no raises. If you get an excellent evaluation, the most you can hope for is 2%. Complain enough and you might get more for at least 1 year. Some employees with little to no experience are paid at the same level as current employees with years of experience. Others are given reclassifications to get a raise and have no additional duties.  Difficult to move up a better position without leaving department and there are few jobs available.

review_title: University of Missouri - Columbia Chemistry department
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: A very good stipend for a university setting in Missouri. Lower cost of living in Missouri compared to other states, There are some helpful faculty/mentors.  Some faculty are very good teachers. It is very clear what is expected of you as a TA.
cons: High cost of living in Columbia compared to other Missouri cities. Some faculty/mentors are very hands off and don't really help improve you professionally (you help yourself or you sink).  You are told that you are a lower caliber of graduate student than at other universities.  TAs are told to make their lab averages higher than they probably should be in most cases so they do not have to hear students complain.

review_title: Great job security, even for those who don't work very hard....
pros: Stable work environment.  No one gets fired.  Great place to work for the pension.  Good insurance rates.  You can get good prices on software from the university book store.  Good software provided to faculty and staff.  Norton Anti-Virus corporate edition is free.  It is a great environment for someone just starting their programming career in that they are given opportunity for training.  Work loads are typically low.
cons:
No one gets fired.  Performance cannot be easily recognized with a substantial salary increase.
Salaries are all percentage-based.  If you start low, you will always be low.  
When the state cuts funding everyone starts worrying about their jobs.

review_title: A good life, but don't expect to get paid....
job_title: Recruiting Coordinator in Kansas City, MO
pros: I love the sense of mission displayed by many faculty and staff members.  The benefits and vacation time are top notch.  The campus is a wonderful place to come to work every day.  And we don't come to work when it snows!
cons: There is just not enough money to go around.  Nearly every staff member is underpaid.  Additionally, working for a state institution tends to breed a "clock-puncher" mentality.  Pay raises are given annually, and the amount is set for everyone.  The review system incentivizes employees not to perform but to simply last.  The system encourages mediocrity rather than performance.

pros: I was able to gain insight into the world of research in Engineering. Depending on the research adviser, Undergraduate Research Assistants may have the potential to choose their own schedule to fit with their course schedule.
cons: Depending on whether the research adviser is paying in full or if the school is funding part of your pay, there is the potential that the maximum amount of hours allowed in a single semester works out to be somewhere around 100 hours in a 16 week period from my understanding of things.

review_title: Great environment, definitely a job to consider!
job_title: Office Support Staff in Columbia, MO
pros: Great co-workers, excellent benefits, friendly environment, room for advancement, wonderful college town, educational-assistance benefits really help out if you're wanting to further your education.  College life on this campus is exceptional, from speaker's circle to brady commons, not to mention the excellent football team. You'll never be short a good time if you're out and about in Columbia!
cons: parking! There isn't much and you are always fighting for a spot. Great if live close enough that you can bike to work! Another downside might be the educational assistance benefit if you're not interested in it. This could be a downside because you aren't getting another benefit in place of this!

pros: It was great to be surrounded by students, faculty, and staff who always sought to learn, research, and grow as professionals.  Mizzou offers amazing academic programs and ways for students, faculty, and staff to get involved on campus and in their community.
cons: As we've seen over the past year, the leadership needed to be replaced at many levels.  It is my hope that new leadership comes in and is able to connect more with the students, faculty, and staff and assist in adjusting the culture to be more diversified and inclusive.

pros: There are many fine professional individuals working on behalf of the university.  Poorly acknowledged on a campus where faculty and leadership offer no support or respect for the efforts of non-academic professionals, many dedicated fundraisers and administrative leaders continue to work on behalf of local students striving to achieve the dream of higher education.
cons: Although the need for a strong commuter campus is clear to those living within the metropolitan area, the faculty arrogance and the leadership from Chancellor to Chairs is sadly lost in ego.  Dollars are appropriated for vanity faculty projects for leader's spouses and/or favored few faculty and the fundraising leadership follows along this unethical path without comment.  Ultimately one is asked to obtain philanthropic dollars from the community at an unrealistic rate, to be spent in an unethical manner.

review_title: Overall, my experience was good.  There was some preference with hiring family members.
job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros: Friendly home town atmosphere, good research facilities with a fair number of scientific collaborations between different departments.  It's easy to accumulate lots of vacations days.
cons: Somewhat isolated from an airport which can be stressful during holiday storms.  My department started to exhibit family preferences for hiring.  This is not atypical at University institutions but it can be uncomfortable for those employees caught in between.  For individuals interested in technical positions, keep in mind that these jobs are "temporary" no matter what was promised during the interview.

pros: Laid back yet challenging environment with a great amount of opportunities for professional development and ongoing education.  MU is a great professional community and the many departments/divisions all respect and work together to ensure collaborative relationships.  Flexible work schedules and a great appreciation for work/life balance.
cons: Pay ranges are not typically great for staff/exempt staff.  Unless you're faculty or in a senior position, it's likely that you will not be compensated for the amount of work you do.  There are minimal raises.

pros: The atmosphere is very laid back, the pay is decent, and the campus is beautiful.  They're flexible with your schedule and there is a lot of room for advancement.
cons: There is little to no leadership or structure.  It's very much a do whatever to make it work type of place.  Training is very much on you to figure things out.   You have to pay for parking and you can't take time off for your first six months.

review_title: Enjoyable and flexible work centered not on the job but on your class schedule.
job_title: Student Lab Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: While attending the University I held a number of on campus jobs and each one was more than willing to taylor to my class schedule. They recognize the main reason you are there is to complete a degree and make sure to keep the priority in order.
cons: Sometimes it can be stressful during finals week or midterms when all the students are in the computer labs and needing to ask questions when you are trying to do the same, yourself, and are bombarded with questions.

review_title: The University of Missouri views its graduate students as grant and patent generating workers rather than as students.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: They do provide decent classroom instruction as well as adequate research facilities. A few of the tenured professors are genuinely concerned with student learning.
cons: The organization cares very much about the revenue that a student can help bring in by working on grant-funded research. However, very little effort is made to ensure that students graduate on time or that they have decent career prospects. As a result, I know many students who finished with a PhD who can not find jobs.

job_title: Research Scientist in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- The pay and benefits were satisfactory.

- Enjoyed working with UMSL students.
cons:
- Certain employees at Missouri Institute of Mental Health (MIMH) were emotionally unstable, rude, condescending, and unpredictable.  The environment there can be toxic and stressful.  I was confronted with unprofessional behaviors quite often, particularly when we were under a time crunch.

- No training was provided at all and expectations were unclear.  I felt confused from day 1. 

- Scientific integrity is thrown out the window often in favor of getting more grant money. 

- Disorganized and chaotic environment.  Despite having access to many resources that could provide stability and infrastructure, these resources were not utilized.  Every task was completed last minute and we were left scrambling to meet every deadline.

- Terrible work life balance.  You could never tell when you were going to asked to work a 12 hour day or longer.

pros: Columbia is a great place to live.
cons: Faculty who stay are satisfied being mediocre; good faculty leave as quickly as possible. Sexism is rampant. Provost and many deans are inexperienced and low quality: they don't act like leaders of a flagship research university.  The university is underfunded and likes flashy marketing programs.  My college's dean and the provost think they are the smartest people in the room, and that faculty are enemies that need to be led through intimidation and fear.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: One of the best aspects is that the scheduling is family friendly, and if you have the time to take, they will usually work with you. UM System also provides paid vacation and sick leave, as well as decent Health Insurance. Generally pretty good about updating Media equipment to keep up with the technological advances of video and audio production.
cons: Unfortunately, this position pays grossly below the industry standard. There are often extra (outside of the ordinary) tasks asked of you, which aren't compensated for, but could be considered resume builders.

review_title: Great environment to learn and grow!
pros: There are endless perks to being a University of Missouri. You have access to many services on campus, get to work with a wonderful, diverse staff and faculty, and have the opportunity to learn from and build relationships with students. From a marketing and writing standpoint, Mizzou has its own set of identity standards and news bureau, so it's wonderful to have the support of strong brand management.
cons: The university is currently recovering from negative media coverage and is at work in restoring its image. Climbing the latter is also difficult because often over-qualified candidates apply for positions.

review_title: It is what you make of it
pros: beautiful campus, so many wonderful things happening.  Most departments are casual.  There are many perks:  Tuition discounts for family members, pretty good benefits (although they keep getting smaller).
cons: While many colleagues are innovative and inspiring, about half of the people appear to be going through the motions and are satisfied with the minimum.  Unless you are an upper level executive, the system consistently underpays and under appreciates.

review_title: Inexperienced management, poor understanding of roles and expectations
job_title: UI/User Experience Designer in Columbia, MO
pros: Tuition discount if attending for a degree
cons:
Over the course of 5 years, I received only one cost-of-living pay rise and no opportunity for professional development.

Frequent turnover in leadership and staff resulted in a toxic work environment.

There was little direction from the multiple layers of management above and within this team. Including a complete absence of product and project management and an inability to articulate what "success" was other than output. That can partly be attributed to placing those with no relevant work experience outside of this university into those management positions, hiring and promoting only with-in, and having high staff turnover due to unrealistic compensation and a dated understanding of the roles commonly found in the technology space.

review_title: Self Betterment with Some Imposed Asceticism
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: Basic benefits are covered.  Health plans are in place for graduate student workers.  Even if the offerings are meager, they are provided.
cons: I can't help but feel like the various graduate assistant roles at the university, along with adjunct faculty, have become a linchpin in keeping everything running, yet at the same time the compensation for these roles doesn't really reflect that.  This is given the tuition waivers that we receive (which don't cover course fees and depending on your department this can be a reasonable chunk of change (between $500-1000) you have to pay out every semester that you may not have been expecting to pay).

review_title: Waste of time to go to work.
job_title: Web Development Intern in Columbia, MO
pros: Very laid back. Allowed me to do homework when I had free time. Work was easy.
cons: Low pay. Low number of hours. Very little work to do. It felt like a waste of time to go in every day.

review_title: It's a Decent Place to Work
job_title: Senior Information Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros: Pretty scenery on campus. Mostly friendly people, but loads of gossip and office politics. Good benefits if and only if you get them. Nice downtown location for lunch if you have time for it. Most people there care about their work, usually more than the people who do the work.
cons: Keeps you exactly under the minimum hours to receive benefits. Cost of parking seems high when the lots and garages are completely over-filled. Pay is generally low for the jobs, even for university standards. Not a lot of work/life balance.

pros: The people you work with are great. It may not be the easiest of work, but the cohesion among employees is outstanding. It is worth the headache most of the time because the reward is great for college students. You are able to learn about proper ettiquette and fine dining all while making a little bit of extra money.
cons: Hours can be long and can sometimes run past your scheduled time. The management is not always the best on communication, but it became rapidly better over the course of my four years there.

review_title: Pretty good place to work, constant network and physical construction are annoying.
pros: The people are great. The University is beautiful. Columbia can be small town or big city, whatever you want.
cons: Something is ALWAYS changing. I've been here 6+ years and there has always been at least one dorm under construction or renovation. I suppose that means the campus is growing but it would be nice to drive on to campus without passing a hard hat zone and all the dust and dirt that goes along with that.

review_title: element of discrimination/prejudice is relevant and still visible
pros: i have none to report
cons: was hired to  work in IT. company hired me and had me move to Columbia from 4 hours away, and in less than 2 weeks allowed supervisor to prejudice myself and the technical position; was forced out because I am not a patsy - and did not want to deal with so much unpreparedness and disorganization. disappointed institution of this size has no concrete training in place - seems tenured employees have gotten by on lipservice and going along just to get along - thats not me.  I did not receive element of respect from supervisor in the animal science building which put a strain on my employment which I was told by HR has no relevance since I was "probationary employee" my concerns were not valid. thanks.

review_title: A cash strapped university that needs to fine tune its priorities.
pros: Great benefits- health, disability, vision, dental, life insurance, decent job security, good physical facilities, University paid retirement (including VERIP). There is also educational assistance for the employee and their family, after a certain period of time.
cons: depending on department the atmosphere can be fantastic or a nightmare. Raises and general pay policies are inconsistent. Evaluation policies and proceedures are inconsistent.  Parking is expensive.

pros:
Values
Office Culture
The benefits are great for my family. I enjoy the health and dental. Also my oldest son gets 50% off tuition at the school since I work here. That helps out a whole lot.
cons:
The pay. Don't expect to make much and don't count on raises either.
Sometimes depending on what happened at the university, you may have to say longer and there were times that I was not paid for my overtime

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: The University is located within walking distance of downtown Columbia and the cost of living in the area is among the cheapest in the nation (although housing rates have been increasing lately)
cons: The Engineering department does not currently guarantee stipends to PhD students. Your income is entirely dependent upon whether your immediate advisor has sufficient funding to cover your stipend. You also will likely graduate without any teaching experience, so good luck applying for positions in academia.

pros: It's an R1 university, which helps on the job market, but depending on your field there is a good chance that your department will only have an average ranking.
cons: The graduate students are heavily exploited, many graduate advisors do little to help students through their program, and staff are severely underpaid. Unionization efforts have helped significantly, but grad student stipends are still fairly low compared to other similar research institutions.

review_title: Decent benefits, but tons of politics and favoritism
pros: Tuition discounts, decent health care plan, retirement plan, working hours, ample sick and vacation time, good job for those who like the status quo
cons: Tons of politics and favoritism, money is wasted on unnecessary expenses while employees remain under compensated, little room for advancement unless you are a "favorite," token communication efforts from management, huge salary and raise discrepancies that depending largely on favoritism and politics

review_title: MU, a great place to start a career.
job_title: Group Project Coordinator in Columbia, MO
pros: The campus is a really great place to be. My department allowed for individuals to take on new responsibilties and add projects as they saw fit. It's a great place to learn and feel connected to a community.
cons: The parking situation is awful. The university is currently experiencing budget cuts which has had an impact on opportunities to travel for professional development (attending conferences and other meetings). I would have to say that the perks far outweigh the downsides of working at the University.

review_title: Great Learning Experience at Campus Dining Services at University of Missouri
pros: I had a great experience learning and working with the managers at Mark Twain Market. The schedule was flexible and they let me bring in my own ideas and creativity to improve the workplace for employees and customers.
cons: As a student it may be difficult to be promoted for the small amount of student management positions available.  Sometimes the shifts you would want to work would get filled up too quickly.

job_title: Office Support Staff in Columbia, MO
pros:
The pros are definitely the benefits and some of the people you work with. 
The insurance is great even though I didn't get to use it long and the ability to take time off or leave early is pretty good. I loved working with one of my coworkers and some of the professors. The students are pretty good too. Normally they need something from you so they are super nice and polite.
cons:
One HUGE downside is that people are super nosy around here. People are always up in your business. They are always asking who someone is and what they are doing there, why someones office door is open. I also had a coworker go through my personal email. 
Another really big downside is the expensive parking. I mean the pay already sucks immensely and they of course take out taxes, insurance, and other benefits, then they take out a chunk for parking. Parking in which unless you show up early, you will be parking on the roof..... if you can find that. Not to mention people will just slam their doors into your brand new car and dent it....
Lastly, the professors. Most are pretty great, super kind, and super appreciative. However, some of the professors are EXTREMELY condescending and downright rude. They are entitled and want things immediately even if you have twelve other people in line in front of them. Their are some that no matter what you do will treat you like crap and will be super rude to you. 
Also, the fact that layoffs are coming really makes morale terrible.

pros: Basically some of the best reasons would be "good environment, more students are present so you can get more beneficial and interesting ideas,   to work on.
cons: I found very few downsides like interview procedures are very long and many phases are there, and the result too take time to come out. Job description does not match with what they ask at the interview.

job_title: Senior Research Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros: I have been employed at UMC for 7 years, it has been an amazing experience.  The benefits are outstanding, haven't heard of better anywhere.  And the the skills and knowledge that I have acquired and first rate.
cons: The salary is not nearly as competitive as you would find working for a private biotech firm, but the ability to learn is unparalleled.

review_title: Ellis Library is A Great and Quiet Place to Work
pros: VERY friendly staff. My coworkers made me feel at home at Special Collections. The jobs you do there differ greatly and sometimes present challenging opportunities to learn new things. And they truly have amazing collections that anyone would find something of a particular interest!
cons: Might be extremely quiet and then the day might go very slow. Also, again, assignments differ greatly, so you might end up helping taping boxes all day long, or assisting with dumping water from the air conditioning system in the toilet.

review_title: Decent place for a student to work while in school.
job_title: Student Technical Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: Was compensated well for working in a student position. Basic office work with decent people around you. Worked well around student schedule
cons: As with most university management is pretty awful and anything out of the ordinary has to go through a bureaucratic goose chase to get completed.

pros: Hours were flexible depending upon how busy the research schedule was at the time.  Management was very helpful in mentoring and helping with career growth.
cons: When there research schedule was demanding then sometimes weekend work was required.  It wasn't every weekend though so that made it easier to deal with.

pros: Nice campus with lots of walking opportunities with lots of botanicals.  Historic buildings contribute to the campus feel and looks.  Devoted facility staff make it work without adequate funds.
cons: Do not be blinded by what seems to be a secure career.  It is not!  Money isn;t even as good as it seems.  Politics play a huge role in how the org functions.

review_title: Service Captain- University Club of MU
pros:
-Free meals on breaks when food is left over from buffets
-Fun coworkers (also students)
-"Employee of the month" type awards, such as a free jacket or dining room lunch for two. 
-on campus location
-limited upward mobility if interested
-some ability to pick your own shifts
-After Dining Room trained, you will be qualified to work at any nice restaurant in the future
-Management is absolutely committed to the highest quality of guest experience. 
-In the Dining Room, you really get to know the regulars (usually influential university officials and professors). It's great to see them around town and stop for a chat even after I left the job.
cons:
-Management pushes you to upsell on drinks, expensive wine, etc., but encourages their guests not to top Dining Room staff. There is a "service charge" on receipts that management tells their guests goes to their server. It absolutely does not. It supposedly goes into a fund to help pay all servers the wage that is legally due to them. This is dishonest to their guests, and morally repugnant. This alone demonstrates the lowest respect for their servers. 
-You can work literally anywhere else in town making tips and make double the money. 
-Some members of the kitchen staff are inconsiderate, verbally abusive, and bring down any good atmosphere staff has been able to create that day. 
-No request off days on Easter, Mother's Day, Father's Day, and 10-15 hour shifts during finals week
-Was told that my schoolwork always comes first, and can request off for studying. The one time I tried to do this (finals week my senior semester), I was scheduled anyway and told that if I didn't work the shifts I would be fired. 
-Extremely unclear about what they expect from employees to be promoted. No system in place. Management was unable to cite any real reasons when an employee asked why they hadn't been promoted, or what they could do to be considered for a promotion.

pros: Work/life balance is pretty good, as are benefits-beyond the standard there is still a pension (although this is probably changing), tuition reimbursement for dependents, lots of vacation and on campus ben's like the rec center.
cons: Can be beurocratic depending on department, professors tend to have huge ego's, raises are very small 2% IF they are approved, hasn't happened in two years due to state budget issues.  It is a recession though...

review_title: I have been treated disrespectfully by a boss who plays favorites and penalizes those who she simply does not like.
pros:
weekends and holidays off and average amount of vacation time earned.
perks such as discounts on tickets to local sports events, theme parks
cons:
no education opportunities despite the fact that it is a "teaching hospital". 
company values the almighty dollar more than patient care.

job_title: Food Prep, Cook, Server, Cashier in Columbia, MO
pros: Wide variety of work experience. If you work at the student center you can choose to work at any of the five different restaurants and get to know the process for preparing different kinds of food. Not bad for a first job as a student honestly, if you're looking for experience in the food industry.
cons: They were a little light on the training. Took me a few days to really figure out the workflow for each restaurant. Also, as a food service worker, the pay isn't exactly competitive compared to other student jobs.

pros: They offer decent medical benefits and when push comes to shove politics are thrown away to do the best thing for the students!
cons: The student body can be extremely rude and demeaning to staff and faculty - the good thing is that adminstration has your back in a tight situations.

review_title: Central HR is an unprofessional mess
pros: Focus on wellness and benefits; had great leaders when I started
cons: All of those great leaders are gone through termination, layoffs, retirements, etc.  There is no positive leadership remaining and the VP has been "interim" for years now.  HRIS functions as an IT unit, not an HR team.  This was the least professional HR team I have seen with people hiding behind others when they don't know what to do.  If you want to work for HR, go to a campus or or hospitals.

pros:
I really enjoy the people I work with.  I feel like the management cares about me and my professional development.
The health benefits are incredible.
cons:
For some positions, the salaries are impressive.  For staff, I believe the salaries could be better.  
Recently, there have been several cuts made at the University.  This is a con but was also unavoidable.

job_title: Office Professional IV in Columbia, MO
pros: Working at a University is a great idea. Especially if you're interested in staying within academia (sort of) for full employees tuition is very cheap!
cons: The chain supply of how things work administratively (sending student back and forth to offices only to have them sent back, etc. There is a department for everything and following the administrative chain was a hassle sometimes.  Also recently healthcare option changed for the worse.

job_title: Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: Good benefits and decent amount of time off.
cons: The biology department is imploding due to lack of administrative support.  They've lost so many good faculty over the years due to poor leadership at every level.  When I first started, there in the 1990s it was awesome.  Thanks to poor leadership at the highest level as well as a board of curators who only know about business, the school has been mostly gutted.

review_title: Great environment and coworkers, but shifting management
pros: Get to work with friends, easygoing work environment, great opportunity to network, flexible work schedule perfect for college students.
cons: Shifting management at my position made it difficult to maintain standards and know who exactly is in charge. My manager at my former job was extremely unprofessional to the point where I felt the need to file a formal complaint with the university.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: The resources and infrastructure here are amazing.  The University does a good job of supporting research and professional advancement of graduate students.
cons: Long hours, short pay, underappreciation by professors, and lots of verbal abuse unless you pick the right advisor.

review_title: If you can deal with BS then it is a good job while attending school.
job_title: Graduate Teachers Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: I love working with my students and the professors.  They did make it worth it.  Plus you get paid along with getting your credit hours paid for.  So for the little pay that you get it is worth it.
cons: In my department there was A LOT of drama between the professors.  It is a small department and rumors and drama always impeded in the learning process

review_title: Good for training but bad for pay
pros: They give people a chance to thrive that normally wouldn't get a chance
cons: They have some of the lowest pay rates of any school of their size.  If you are a kiss up you can move up, but if you keep your head down and work hard you will most likely stay in place.

review_title: My employment at the University of Missouri has afforded me a wide array of opportunities for growth and experience.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: The university has a wide range of opportunities and a vast diversity of jobs, designed to be attractive to a a wide audience.
cons: Most jobs offered by the University are not designed to provide significant opportunities for advancement. This, however, may not be a problem for some people.

review_title: Well organized and supportive atmosphere for scientific research.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Columbia, MO
pros: Autonomy is the key. As a research scientist I was given leeway to explore projects in my own ways, and there was support when I needed it, both from my supervisor and from the office staff.
cons: I don't think this is a con, but you'd have to enjoy living in a small college town to work here. That being said, I truly enjoyed Columbia as a city. They are very forward-thinking despite their size and location in the middle of nowhere.

review_title: University of Missouri - International Center - Research Assistant
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros:
- Exciting to work with international students, one of MU's fastest growing markets 
- Fantastic coworkers
- Coworkers were not only well-trained for their jobs and subject-matter experts, but also cared about their customers and believed in the importance of their work
- Culture of hard work and positive attitudes
- Senior leaders and employees gave me support to succeed in my work
cons:
- Low hourly pay (offset by free tuition) 
- Lots of time in a cubicle
- Repetitive work
- Few growth opportunities

pros: It was okay, found a lot of holes in training and it was not what i expected at first im just doing this for the free access
cons: I have never worked here and am just entering this so I can see the reviews I want. I will add a review when I get a real job sorry sorry sorry sorry sorry

pros: Honestly, there were great people and the atmosphere was pleasant.  People were helpful and really seemed to care that you have what you need to do the job and learn.
cons: Not much to discuss.  Just have to make sure you find the right pace for yourself.  Some roles are slower, some are more intense.

pros: Hours are flexible, and made to fit a student's schedule. Those I have worked directly with have been competent and helpful, and are pleasant to work with.
cons: Experience varies wildly by department. The upper administration is generally out of touch and ineffective, and the diversity of employees is appallingly low. Part-time pay is generally minimum wage or close to it.

review_title: Great place to work, but they're super cheap
pros:
Very laid back work space
Nice people
Paid time and a half for overtime and double for holidays
A very very secure job for film
Good benefits
cons: Their rate of pay is severely lower than the average rate of pay for this profession in Missouri or elsewhere. Their initial offer was only $13 and hour, but I was able to use some leverage to budge them up to $17 during salary negotiations. The woman in charge of the video department was extremely rude always.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: In the heart of Kansas City. Employment opportunities upon graduation. Business friendly city, so plenty of internships available while attending school.
cons: Horrible payscales for students. A student instructor gets the same pay as a Graduate Teaching Assistant or grader for a course. Although faculty is well-accomplished, there aren't many positions for research assistants due to lack of grants. Extremely expensive.

review_title: I am a graduate research assistant at the University of Missouri.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: I will obtain a Masters of Science in Electrical Engineering. As a graduate research assistant I receive a tuition waiver and health insurance subsidy, albeit for very bad insurance. Overall the experience has been incredibly challenging but will be well worth it in the end.
cons: Graduate research assistants really don't have much of a life. Depending on your advisor and your passion for the project you are working on, your experience will vary greatly.

pros: Benefits are awesome!  Salaries are average for the area, but could be higher for some hard to find skill sets.  IT top management is great and were awesome to work for.  Could not ask for better managers in IT.
cons: Salaries in some technical areas could be higher.  Some typical large state university politics, but the IT department seemed to be insulated from it.

pros: The hours are flexible, the pay is more than fair, and you get to manage yourself. If you like helping others with their problems, this is an ideal job.
cons: Over the past two years, I didn't really run into anything that I disapproved of. I suppose the only problem I had was that sometimes a session would get packed with too many students and it was difficult to help everyone a fair amount, but this was not a big issue very often.

review_title: Expand your skills... just don't expect to be paid for it
job_title: Senior Communications Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: The employees are generally nice and really care about creating a positive environment for student learning.
cons:
Thanks to state budget cuts and dwindling enrollment, pay raises are nonexistent (at least for those toward the bottom of the food chain). It's not uncommon for job duties to expand way beyond the scope of your original position, but good luck getting an appropriate title and raise for that work.

And, of course, the administration is a mess right now.

review_title: Very rewarding experience at a time when I needed the positive environment.
pros: Collegial atmosphere, relatively low pressure environment, freedom to peruse educational opportunities-skills enhancement. Wide variety of people to work with. Relative freedom to problem solve on specific project needs.
cons: Advancement not encouraged by specifics from supervisors, beyond an 'atta boy'. Raises and continued employment problematic due to fickle funding.

review_title: Everything that glitters is not black and gold
pros: Way too much PTO! Catered meals occasionally. Great co-workers
cons: If you're not in the "in crowd" you aren't advancing. Supervisors do not practice due diligence on personnel issues. Next to no raises. Now have to take a week furlough with no pay, decreasing income by 2% for the year.

pros: The recreation center is stellar, and the city is relatively small and pleasant. There doesn't seem to be much racial prejudice on campus.
cons: There is nobody in charge: tenured faculty do whatever they want, disregarding University policy whenever they want, and the University does nothing. Students are treated like they are children. Academic records have been "lost" at critical times (e.g. just before graduation). Bizarre thing happened, like a tenured journalism faculty blocked reporters from doing their job, and certain students with possibly untrue agendas banded together to get people fired. Not a happy place to work.

job_title: Associate Teaching Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: In my experience, there is great colleagiality and very interesting students as well as supportive administration and amazing technology resources to assist in reaching students.
cons: Lack of state funding makes every department spread too thin.  Most teaching faculty have a 20% service load that frequently requires significantly more than 20% of one's time to complete.

job_title: Business Technology Analyst in Columbia, MO
pros: Laid back atmosphere and the employees are nice to work with for the most part. They are usually good about letting you have time off.
cons: Lack of leadership in top, middle and lower management. Pay raises are non-existent due to budgetary constraints and it has been that way for a few years.

job_title: Executive Staff Assistant in Ashland, MO
pros: Great environment, beautiful campus, decent benefits, many opportunities to learn and advance skillset
cons: As an hourly employee in order to get decent wage increases you have to transfer around, as most departments don't give bonuses and raises are typically less than 3%.

pros: It's a very easy job, and you don't even need to like people all that much to do it. All you need is some common sense and you'll get paid to mostly watch Netflix and study.
cons: Residential Life itself is horrible. Typical management problems. Prepare for inadequate bosses (it's okay, you'll rarely see them) who implement silly rules.

pros: I enjoyed working for campus dining: the hours were flexible and the people were nice. Employees are given meals during shifts and most employees are very friendly.
cons: My job required my working on nights and weekends, which is not ideal. (Often until 2 or 3 AM.) Some of the full time employees acted like they did not want to be there.

job_title: Center Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros: MU is a strong academic institution with a focus on research and teaching, as well as economic development and community outreach.
cons: Some programs do not adequately emphasize the important of generating revenue to support operations, and others are more focused on gaining visibility and standing for individuals rather than for developing the program as a whole.

pros:
Average longevity in my department is near 10 years
Work/Life balance is stressed
Very positive and encouraging environment
Fringe benefits of working for a University are excellent
Medical benefits are excellent compared to other local companies
cons:
The University is a very large employer and as a result many departments and functions are very siloed. A company this size is not for everyone. 
There is a lot of redundancy due to segmentation of functions
Funding is difficult to find at the present time

review_title: A place with a mission or clear vision.
pros: Nice campus -- good place to visit.
cons: Support staff is undervalued. Opportunities for creativity is limited. Educational benefits are extremely stingy. 5 years until employees dependents get any break on their tuition. Educational benefits for employees are skimpy....just a dozen or  so evening classes.

review_title: Neutral is the most fitting description.
pros: Low cost of living, nice town.  Academics are reasonably good... for the south.  Run a little too much like a corporation.
cons: Public transportation is meager at best.  Facilities crew is likely overworked, but nonetheless under performs, often severely. Some (definitely not all) undergraduates are reckless and rude.

pros: Common: Decent benefits, verbose emails from leadership to CYA, facilities, job security (never ending paper pushing), burnt out/disengaged staff/faculty, and continuous budget cuts.
cons: Rare: Action-driven leadership, accountability, personal responsibility, promotions, raises, acknowledgment, good parking, intra-departmental collaboration, forward thinking, funding, quality courses, responsive campus public relations, productivity, wasteful spending, national prominence, attaining talented recruits, and employee retainment.

pros:
Supervisors really treat you like people
Work does not go unnoticed
Always room for innovation
Great environment and place to work - the town and school are both fantastic!
cons: There really were not many downsides to working here. I worked in an hourly position and sometimes the pay could have been a little better, but I didn't mind too much.

review_title: reasonable workload, but limited career advancement opportunities...
pros:
Laid back working culture
Supportive staff.  Most staff members are very profession and have done great jobs.  
Work - life balance
Majority of people are friendly and great to work with
cons:
Very few opportunities for professional growth or advancement
Some admin/faculty see employee/staff as dispensable items or THE HELP
The payment is lower than the average rate
Politics

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: It is nice to be in an environment of learning, and get paid (albeit a paltry sum) to learn and teach.
cons: The students at the University of Missouri are sub-standard.  They seem to not care about anything outside of where the next party is, and what sorority/fraternity they are in.

pros: Extension: Fellow employees almost all nice. Work is interesting, challenging, and rewarding. It’s good to work on campus
cons: Arbitrary leadership, sometimes it feels like change is being made just for the sake of change. Management seemingly is totally deaf to employees. Doesn’t listen, not sure how much they care. Sometimes downright hostile. Very much play favorites. Very little room for advancement.

pros: Good benefits (healthcare, wellness incentive, plenty of HR support), opportunities to move around laterally, things move at a fairly slow pace. Working on a college campus is fun, there's lots going on all the time.
cons: Pay is not competitive with corporate jobs, although some colleges and departments are much better than others. Slow pace, inefficient processes, and lots of red tape can be frustrating if you have never worked for a public institution before.

review_title: Good but sometimes demanding Work Terrible Pay
pros: Great learning environment with some room for error. Good Benefits. Good co-workers. Fairly flexible schedules and telecommute.
cons: Absolutely lousy pay and slow advancement no matter how driven one is. Can be incredibly demanding on small teams with on call rotations etc.... Some "customers" are out of touch with what is possible. Went to a different company and more than doubled my salary.

review_title: They don't care the benefit of the staff and students except professors.
pros:
It's close to Metrolink.
You can use lots of facilities for free.
Salary is not bad.
You can have some trainings.
cons: They are extremely concerning about the professor, so, if unfortunately you have conflict with a professor, you will get into lots of trouble. Downside of public University.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros: I have loved having the opportunity to work on real world projects and problems.  It has been incredibly educational and I have grown a lot as a person because of it.
cons: I think one of the cons is that your educational and work experience is dependent on the faculty that teach or employ you.  I believe that this can either make for a great or horrible experience depending on the faculty member.

pros: The health care insurance that uses the university health care system is very comprehensive in its coverage and there are many specialists available.
cons: Due to declining enrollment and budget cuts, the faculty are having to take on larger class sizes and staff is worried about layoffs. Thus the atmosphere is somewhat stressful. The university recently increased the cost of health insurance for future retirees.

job_title: Lab Assistant in Kansas City, MO
pros:
Get a chance to work with people from different places
gain more knowledge while interacting with others
able to increase managerial skills
cons:
Management is not up to the expectation. 
In some places the informations services is not up to mark.
It is better for work study students

review_title: It was a great experience that gave me good experience in how to satisfy costumers.
pros: They work around your schedule and are very willing to help with schedule changes if they are necessary. It is a great working environment and they tell you where you stand with reports every 2-3 weeks.
cons: Because of people's schedules, weekly meeting times changes a lot, which sometimes became confusing, especially if an email had the wrong time on it.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbia, MO
pros: Lots of opportunities to meet others, a world-class education, and a great atmosphere for research and innovation.  The recreation facility is also great, and the health-care benefits are very competitive.
cons: The city of Columbia is quite small, making networking challenging, but the town is relatively close to the bigger cities of St. Louis and Kansas City.

pros:
Work/life balance
Bosses are nice and understanding
Get help where you need it
Job security 
Great, cheap health and dental benefits
cons:
Promised growth may take many years
Political environment
Raises are across the board and you have to move positions to make money (but it is possible)

review_title: Too much change for such stagnation
job_title: Business Support Specialist in Columbia, MO
pros: Lot of career paths, great schedule, great benfits
cons: Positions always in flux, no stability, no recognition at ground-level for employee achievements, no clear path for promotions, lack of raises

pros:
Easy
Interactive
Social
Good pay and hours

The best part is, in my opinion, that you're not encouraged to sell the customer products they don't need
cons:
Management sometimes doesn't know what's going on
The work can sometimes get boring but most of your coworkers are interesting enough to keep you from getting bored

pros: concentrated engineering at rolla missouri, nice school, good infra structure everything is good and everything is still good... because i have to fill this up for 20 words and i dont know y
